text:
CHIT-CHAT LOCALS.

Gathered by our Reporters.

Telegraph communication is all O.K. here once more.

Mr. J. W. Hard has returned back to the house on the hill.

Mr. R. M. Martin is expected back from Wisconsin next week.

The Rev. Caleb Parker arrived back from Saskatchewan Wednesday.

A. G. Goodall and family recently arrived from Hamilton, Ont., on Friday last.

Some of the police stationed here have started the potato patch on the French estate.

Constable McMurrin will leave the Police Force in June on the arrival of Capt. Anderson, his father having bought into another company.

We received this week a copy of the Post Muday Co., a column of news and opinion, which can be seen at the office of Mr. W. W. MacLuse.

Mets, R. L. F. Anderson and T. Taylor are building a stock yard back of the West End Telegraph offices for Moses, O. H. Frinnson & Co. It will be used for trading purposes.

Mrs. Whittal and son arrived back on Saturday last, on a visit to their son, Mr. Tom Smith, in Prince Albert; they have been in charge of the steamer laid up here during the winter.

Dodgers are out asking for tenders for hauling steamer supplies. Esmond and Collins of Regina and specialists, are now at the office of Mr. W. W. Macluse.

M. R. Hard was paid a visit yesterday by his son Frank, who visited here last summer and exchanged business matters.

Mr. Thomas Swinton of England, has been in charge of the steamer laid up here during the winter.

Mrs. Thompson brought her son, Mr. E. H., here a week ago, and he is staying with Mr. Anderson.

CAMPBELL'S, C. S. K.

First Case by Express

The farmers are complaining of want of rain.

Our lacrosse teams are practicing every day in anticipation of action with our summer class.

Three births in town last week.

Population increasing.

Uniforms.

Annie Park returned back from Battelfoeld last Sunday.

Look out for the Calculus games on the Queen's Birthday.

Don't forget the P. A. C. Band drama the evening of Monday, the 28th of May.

Mr. J. Campbell, who has been abroad for a few weeks in the past two weeks, is rapidly recovering.

The Rev. Dr. Smith, M.A., of the University of Oxford was in Lahore last week and was engaged in an effort to raise funds for the Orphan asylum of Galapagos on his mission there.

The other day a young lady passed our office she was impressed in reading a certain line from the Bible. We consider it very satisfactory.

The New French Half Breed law is now being put into operation.

The leaders of the various governments and corporations that held meetings this week did not promote the government with regard to Half Breed relief, and also that they could not meet the people in order to view Louis Kind of Montana.

Terrible accidents happen, Why do we see that those who are opposed to the Bill, it is probable that if anything does happen it will be at Battleford on Dominion day.

There is plenty of red and natural rubber and there is plenty of incident going to distinguish the governments and corporations, but it seems that they have permitted the government with regard to Half Breed relief, and also that they could not meet the people in order to view Louis Kind of Montana.

The Government of the Canadian Government has succeeded in compelling the Enactment of the Edwina Roberts Act.

This week a new Act has been passed by the legislative council.

There is plenty of red and natural rubber and there is plenty of incident going to distinguish the governments and corporations, but it seems that they have permitted the government with regard to Half Breed relief, and also that they could not meet the people in order to view Louis Kind of Montana.

CAMPBELL'S, C.S.K.

PINEVILLE, May 15.—Great preparations are being made for the celebration next month. The citizens are making grand plans to celebrate this event.

The Toronto and Ottawa Railway was opened last Monday, and trains are running regularly and making good time.

Canadians.

Heavy snow travel by land, air transport, steamships, or railroads has been most successful.

It takes more than a thousand pounds of pressure to break down wood, and tens of thousands of pounds to break down metal.
THE PRINCE ALBERT TIMES
AND SASKATCHEWAN REVIEW

SPINK & MAVEETY

PRINCE ALBERT, N.W.T.

TIGHT BINDING

PROVINCIAL RIGHTS

The people of Manitoba and the North West Territories have for long past been struggling by every legitimate means to secure their rights. They have been treated with great injustice, and they have been denied the opportunity to express their views in a manner which would be acceptable to the government. The government has been unwilling to listen to their complaints, and they have been forced to take matters into their own hands. They have been willing to use any means necessary to secure their rights, and they have been willing to risk everything to achieve their goals.

NEWFOUNDLAND

The results of this attempt to establish a colony in Newfoundland have been disastrous. The colony was established in 1621, but it was not until 1783 that it became officially recognized as a separate entity. However, even then, the colony faced many challenges. The colony was located in a remote area, and it was difficult to maintain contact with the outside world. The colony also faced many economic difficulties, and it was unable to sustain itself financially.

NOTICE

CANADA

In the goods North West Territory, Mr. McKAY, storekeeper, wishes to inform his customers that he has received a large shipment of goods from England. These goods include a variety of items such as clothing, shoes, and household supplies. Mr. McKay also has a large selection of fresh produce available for purchase.

PUBLIC NOTICE

All persons are hereby notified to take notice that the following notice is hereby given: The sale of liquor by the Minister of Justice or the Board of Control is prohibited by law, and all persons who sell or consume liquor in violation of this law shall be liable to prosecution.

BATTLEFIELD ITEMS.

BATTLEFIELD, May 16th, 1884.

For the second time, Col. Hackett has been here this week.

Major Conner is to be in command of the detachment. He left Regina on the 15th last week for the purpose of recruiting. Col. Hackett returns to Regina shortly and when he arrives he will proceed to the place for which he has been transferred.

Dr. Miller has been transferred to this post and is expected daily.

QUEEN'S BIRTHDAY.

A list of events to be held under the auspices of the St. Andrews Society of Prince Albert on the 24th of May.

JAMES SINCLAIR
Merchant Tailor,
and Dealer in

TERRITORIAL NEWS

CALGARY
From the News, April 28.
A trial trip between this point and Edmonton will be made. Probably a fortnightly mail will be established.

Prairie fires have been very destructive. One near here last week was large.

Cass McTavish has a force of men busy at work on the experimental farms.

The harvest here is nearly done. The wheat, oats, barley and peas. The grain saved last fall is exhibiting signs of life.

M. A. C. Sparrow just arrived from Belly River with 200 head of choice beef steers, selected from the different ranges of that district.

A prominent Jew, familiarly known as "Cracker Box Bill," was arrested at Summit for smuggling in goods from the United States. After an interview with Major Dunning, he passed into his cheque for $250 and costs.

PRINCE ALBERT, April 29.
The bridge over the Moose has been completed, and the barges have been pulling in the wood, using as a wharf. This is utilizing the bridge in earnest.

A welcome rain descended on Thursday, which was greatly needed.

The beautiful rain descended on Friday, and kept us all night, and didn't even go home after the morning. All classes in the afternoon took it in short time.

A half breed came in today probably from the mountains with his feet badly swollen.

Considerable activity observable on the streets today.

Mr. J. K. Smith has the first herd of registered thoroughbreds raised in Calgary.

There was a theft at the store's hide day or two ago, but no assault type. The thief was C. O. Smith who has yet been discovered of the theft.

MINNE-JAW
From the News, May 7.
A swan was recently shot by an Indian near Minne-Jaw. It was between noon and 1 o'clock, but the bird was killed.

Navigation on the Moose Jaw has reopened, and those of our citizens who desire to travel by water will find it of any kind will do so, but we are in making the most of the opportunity for travel.

Dr. J. Knott, D.L.S., and party leave here in a few days on an exploratory survey for the Dominion Government at the mouth of the Moose River Bay. His party began at the Forks of the Saskatchewan and came down to Lake Winnipeg, thence down the Nelson River to the Hudson Bay, up the side to Churchill, from which point he follows up the Churchill River, which is well equipped with charts, maps, photographs and magnetic instruments.

MANITOBA.

SIDNEYALL.
From the News, May 3.
Light snow shown on Tuesday. Prairie fires have been raging west of here.

The Regina Daily Sun has passed away, and will be called for publication weekly.

Large numbers of agricultural implements now being shipped from here to farmers in this vicinity.

A petition is circulating in a County Court at present. There is every probability that we will have a new road.

BAT PORRIDGE.
From the Frontier, April 26.
Mr. Robert Shaw, Crown Timber Inspector for the Winnipeg district, has returned from the field. He has reported information that a portion of the crown land in the area has been during the past year used for the raising of livestock.

He has sent a large quantity of wood in different parts of the town.

Fur Trade.
A proposal has been presented to Mr. J. K. Heydon, Dominion Licence Inspector, signed by the majority of the C.P.R. members, requesting that the company be asked to sell liquor between Rat Portage and Edmonton.

Mr. Wm. McCarty returned from Winnipeg last Thursday. While there he disposed of a number of his own Coney Island stock, several Western goods, and then will erect new buildings during the coming season.

Henry E. Hurd.
